ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Resale levy)


    1. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Minister for National Development (a)

Column: 441

how much has been collected from the Housing and Development Board (HDB) resale levy over the past 10 years; (b) what happens to the money collected; (c) whether the HDB resale levy is considered high compared to the subsidy given per flat in today's market; and (d) what plans are there to do a review of this levy.

    The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, the objective of the resale levy is to reduce the housing subsidy enjoyed by those buying their second subsidised flat from the HDB. When second-timers sold their first subsidised flat, they would have cashed in the subsidy that they enjoyed on their first flat. The resale levy therefore helps to discourage over-consumption of public housing subsidies by these second-timer families. This ensures that housing subsidies are fairly allocated between them and first-timer families, who have more pressing housing needs. I must emphasise that flat owners are not required to pay the resale levy if they do not purchase a second subsidised flat from the HDB.

    The resale levy collected by the HDB is used to partially offset its expenditure on home ownership subsidies. The amount collected during the period FY 1992 to FY 2001 can be found in HDB's annual reports. The average amount collected per year is about $170 million. This is a small sum when we compare it to the net amount of $750 million per year that the HDB incurred over the same period to subsidise its home ownership activities.

    The resale levy is graded so that lessees of smaller flats, whom we recognise may have a greater need to upgrade, pay a lower levy rate. The subsidy enjoyed by these families is still attractive compared to the resale levy that they have to pay. And, in fact, this is why second-timer families return to the HDB for a second subsidised flat.

    Home ownership has always been an important facet of our public housing

Column: 442

policy. It has helped us to achieve greater social stability and engendered a sense of community and belonging to Singapore. There is a need for us to balance the allocation of our home ownership subsidies carefully, to ensure that they go to those who need it most. The resale levy policy is an important tool through which we achieve this. It is still relevant in today's context, and therefore we have no plans to review or remove it.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, four supplementary questions.

    First, in view of new flats being sold for almost $1/2 million in the market, what is the Government's subsidy per unit for a flat costing almost $1/2 million?

    Second, where the subsidy is through a Government grant of up to $50,000 for staying near the parents, the resale levy imposed can be seen to be more than two times the grant given for bigger units. The question is: is HDB aiming to profit from this grant if the levy is more than $50,000? Can the homeowner have the option of returning the grant instead of paying the levy?

    Third, for owners who are not sure whether they want to get a second bite of the subsidised cherry flat, but they are not making a profit from the subsidised flat, can this resale flat levy policy be waived for them?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: I thought he said he had four supplementary questions. I counted three.

    First, the subsidy which HDB provides is in the form of a market subsidy, and that is clear to anyone buying an HDB flat, because they know that when they subsequently sell it after the minimum occupation period, they sell it at a price which is higher than what they originally purchased from HDB. It is a matter of timing and definition as to exactly how much that sum is.

    The point is that the resale levy is not a capital gains tax. It is not related to the

Column: 443

notional or actual profit that you would have made from cashing in your subsidy.. This is a policy tool to ensure that people do not unnecessarily come back for a second bite of the subsidy cherry. At the end of the day, remember that there is a finite amount which Government can direct towards housing subsidies. The more we allocate to people taking a second bite, the less we have for people who are taking a first bite.

    I think Mr Steve Chia's supplementary questions are missing this point. It is not a matter of how much the homeowner actually made when he sold his flat, nor is it a matter of whether it was a profit or a loss. It is a matter of directing people so that they do not unnecessarily consume housing subsidies.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin (Holland-Bukit Panjang): Sir, may I ask the Minister of State whether the HDB will consider reducing the resale levy for 3-room flats so as to encourage growing families staying in 3-room flats to upgrade to a 4-room flat?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Mr Speaker, Sir, since May 1977, the resale levy for a 3-room flat is 20%. For people who do their sums, it is still financially viable for them to sell their 3-room flat and subsequently come back for a second bite of a subsidised HDB 4-, 5-room or Executive flat, and they will still be ahead financially. So, the levy, in that sense, is not an impediment or an obstacle to them upgrading. Obviously, because the levy is graduated, for those who are already in 4- or 5-room flats, depending on the exact circumstances of the case and on the timing of the sale and purchase, it may not be sensible for them to come back for a second bite of the cherry.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Sir, the Minister of State has not answered my question on the unit subsidy per flat for those flats that are sold for almost $1/2 million. The Minister for National Development had been quoted in the papers as saying that a $150,000 new flat is very affordable in the market. So, what is the subsidy that the Government is giving for this flat?

Column: 444



    The other question that the Minister of State has not answered me is: will the Ministry consider waiving the resale levy when the houseowner actually makes a loss when selling his subsidised flat?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am unable to give him the exact number for the subsidy of a notional flat which is sold for $1/2 million, because it depends on where the flat is and when it was bought. I cannot give him a specific number to that question.

    His second question is on whether the levy can be waived.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Whether the houseowner has the option to return the $50,000 grant if the grant is actually lower than the resale levy that he has to pay.

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: He cannot subsequently decide that he does not want the housing grant in the first place and therefore is not affected by the resale levy policy. We do not allow people to play the rules retrospectively.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Can the Minister of State explain why it is not allowed?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: If we allow people to play these games retrospectively, we are going to create much more complexity and probably much more unfairness in a system which is no longer transparent and clear. We have a clear set of policies. Remember that no one is compelled to buy a flat from the HDB. Even if a person wants to buy an HDB flat, he is not compelled to come and buy a subsidised flat from the HDB.

    The more important point, in fact, about the resale levy is that if a homeowner does not come back for a second subsidised flat, he cashes out the housing grant and he does not have to pay any levy. That is the important point. It is entirely up to them to do their sums and decide what is sensible and what is not. We are not here to create a system in which people can play games with the rules, change the rules retrospectively and decide which

Column: 445

ones apply to them and which do not apply to them.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Sir, owners are not sure whether they want to buy a second subsidised flat but it is very certain that their first subsidised flat that they bought from the HDB was at a higher price when the market was very high. Subsequently, five years later, when they sell the flat, it is actually below their purchase price, effectively, making a loss. If they are not very sure whether they want to buy a second subsidised flat, then they would need to pay the levy upfront. For such a case, will the Minister of State consider waiving the levy? Because, effectively, they made a loss from buying and selling a subsidised flat.

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Sir, it is the same issue again. I keep emphasising that this is not a tax on profit. Whether a houseowner has made a profit or loss is irrelevant. Let me state it explicitly. The levy is to discourage people from coming back unnecessarily for a second bite of the subsidy cherry.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Chia, can you ask the next Question, please?

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Question 2, Sir.

Column: 445

SECOND PAY-TV AND SATELLITE DISHES


    2. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Acting Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (a) what are the reasons allowing for a second pay-TV operator to enter our small domestic market, when satellite dishes will have been more cost-effective; and (b) when will satellite dishes be approved for the consumer market.

    The Senior Minister of State for Information, Communications and the Arts (Mr Khaw Boon Wan) (for the Acting Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts): Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr Steve Chia is

Column: 446

correct in saying that Singapore's broadcasting market is small. There are only one million households. This small market is further divided among various racial and language groups. That is why the Government's broadcasting competition policy cannot simply copy those of others.

    The approach we have taken is to introduce competition incrementally. Over the last seven years, we have had a single pay-TV operator. That has allowed Singaporeans to enjoy a much wider range of programming than before.

    The question now is whether the market can support a second pay-TV operator. Our industry consultants have studied the problem and concluded that the market could support one more operator. This is why we have decided to offer just one additional pay-TV licence. Even then, we cannot be sure that there is market interest in this licence, or that if awarded, the second licensee will be viable. However, this is an assessment best left to interested industry parties.

    The upside of having a second pay-TV operator is that the competition would help to build a more dynamic and vibrant media industry in Singapore. It would encourage greater innovation and experimentation. It would also facilitate the development of convergent applications and increase the sophistication of the Singapore marketplace. Consumers could benefit from new and improved pay-TV service offerings.

    As for our satellite dish policy, this has been debated several times in this House before. The installation of satellite dishes for households was disallowed to keep out undesirable content that is at odds with our multi-racial and multi-religious society, and to prevent the influencing of Singapore politics from a distance. This was why we built up the cable network, so that Singaporeans would nonetheless be able to enjoy a wider range of programmes. Households have therefore not lost out on programming variety by not having satellite reception.

Column: 447



    But the reasons why we should not allow undesirable contents from easy access to the living rooms of Singaporeans through satellite dishes remain. Security challenges faced by the region, such as the uncovering of terrorist networks here in Southeast Asia, have brought home the reality that we must continue to be vigilant against influences that may split or divide our society.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Sir, since the Senior Minister of State agrees that Singapore is a very small market, is it not more cost-effective to allow individual households to install satellite dishes instead of having a second agency to do that?

    The second question relates to the Senior Minister of State's reply about regulation of undesirable content. There seems to be a contradiction here, because if the Ministry does not seem to be able to regulate and control undesirable content on the Internet, especially with the advancement of broadband, why is there a need to control satellite? Is there not inefficiency or a contradiction in the policy here?

    Mr Khaw Boon Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the market is small, and Mr Steve Chia therefore argued that it is more cost-effective to just allow households to put up satellite dishes. The most cost-effective means for them is to subscribe to the existing pay-TV operator. Mr Steve Chia may have the impression that putting up satellite dishes is a cheap proposition. It is not. The fact that we are able to go for this current policy of disallowing satellite dishes by wiring up is because we are quite unique. We are a very small and compact country. This is one of those few advantages of being small. If we have a huge hinterland, like most other countries, our current policy will be harder to implement. But because we are small and compact, it is quite inexpensive for us to wire up. There are one million homes and, in fact, more than 90% are high-rise HDB flats. The cost of wiring up a home works out to less than - I am relying on memory here - $300

Column: 448

per home. If you put up a dish, a good dish costs almost $1,000. And one dish can only receive a particular satellite up in the sky. So if you want the full works of things, then you need several dishes per home. So it is not cost-effective at all. But, of course, if you have a large country with huge rural areas, that is a different proposition. Then insisting that banning the dishes and wiring up everybody may not be a good solution.

    More importantly for us is not only it is cost-effective to cable up, cabling up allows us new opportunities because at the end of the day, optic fibres can provide a much wider spectrum of frequencies than wireless can provide. It is not quite there yet today because the signals are still analogue but, in due course, I expect the cable network to turn digital. Then you would have a wide spectrum of channels to work with. So that is the reason why in Singapore, we go for cabling as against allowing domestic homes to put up dishes. It is a unique situation that we are facing, and it is a unique advantage that we are exploiting. Whether the market, as I said, can accommodate a second pay-TV operator using some other platforms, it is for the industry to decide. Technologically, it is possible to go on a second platform using copper wires (telephone wires), which are already into every home with ADSL technology. But that is for the market to decide.

    Mr Steve Chia's second point that there is a contradiction, that with Internet, we seem helpless because you can get any content that you want, then why bother to tighten up on satellite transmission of broadcasting materials? If Mr Steve Chia truly believes that through Internet you can get all and sundry - I do not know whether he subscribes to cable TV, but I do - and there are 300,000-over families in Singapore who do the same thing - if he is right, that you can already get anything that you want through Internet, then they must be fools to subscribe to cable TV. So, obviously, this banning of dishes has been effective and serves a useful purpose. And for as long as it does, the ban stays.

Column: 449

IRIS RECOGNITION SYSTEM


    3. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what is the reason for developing and testing an iris recognition system, since Singapore already has the Immigration Automated Clearance System (IACS) which is working effectively; (b) how much does it cost to develop each system; and (c) what will happen to the newly setup IACS.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr Steve Chia asked why the Singapore Immigration and Registration is developing and testing an iris recognition system when the Immigration Automated Clearance System (IACS) is working effectively.

    Let me begin by explaining what the IACS is about. The IACS is an automated immigration clearance system that leverages on biometric technology to identify the travellers. The fingerprint of the traveller is stored in a smart card and then used to match the actual live fingerprint presented by the traveller during immigration clearance. ICAS not only does away with the need for an immigration officer to man each clearance counter, it also enhances security.

    The IACS is not a new system, as Mr Steve Chia seems to suggest. It was first implemented at Changi Airport in 1997. It was extended to Tuas and Woodlands Checkpoints in 1998 and 1999 respectively for bus travellers. The cost of implementing the ICAS is $13 million. We have not implemented the ICAS for motorcyclists after a trial in 1999, because the total clearance time could not meet our operational requirement.

    Sir, biometrics technology is a fast evolving field. International research has shown that iris recognition, which works by scanning and matching the human iris pattern, has a very high level of accuracy and is faster compared to fingerprint matching. Hence, SIR decided to conduct an iris recognition trial for about 3,000 motorcyclists on a voluntary basis at the land checkpoints from June to December

Column: 450

last year to test the feasibility of implementing it on a full scale for the motorcycle lanes.

    This will not only reduce manpower, but more importantly, it will also enhance the level of security without increasing the clearance time. The trials at the Woodlands and Tuas Checkpoints cost about $300,000 each. SIR is now evaluating the results of the trial which seem to be quite encouraging.

    Singapore is not the only country that is exploring the latest biometrics technology to enhance security. Under the current security situation, countries such as the United States, Australia, Japan are also on the lookout for advanced biometrics technology for deployment at their checkpoints.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Sir, why was there not much thought given to the IACS system when it was set up? Is it because the Ministry has been given too much money, so they spend on this, and then later they find that another system ---

    Mr Speaker: Mr Chia, just ask your question. No speeches.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: The question is: why is there not much thought given? And is there a new system coming forth in a few years' time to replace the iris system again? Are we spending too much money on this?

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: If Mr Steve Chia had listened to my answer clearly, he would have known that I said that such biometric technology evolves and is fast changing. At that time in 1997, fingerprint recognition seemed to be the better alternative, iris technology was still quite new. And now we have a new one too called facial recognition. All these systems change all the time. When we decided to do the IACS in 1997, we decided that it was a good system to be implemented in both the land and airport checkpoints, and it served our purpose. There is no waste of money.

Column: 451

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question (28th February, 2003),



    "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 2003 to 31st March, 2004.". - [Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance].



    Question again proposed.


11.26 am

    Mr Othman Haron Eusofe (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, we face formidable challenges in a world which is changing rapidly and radically. To me, the thrust and the message of the Budget Statement and the ERC Report is clear. To succeed in this new increasingly competitive environment, Singaporeans must be ready for a mindset change. The Economic Review Committee has come out with various recommendations, including some radical ones, to ensure that we are able to keep pace with the changes and meet the challenges effectively. As many Members have emphasised, it is crucial that the recommendations are implemented quickly so that we keep ahead of our competitors. It will not be easy or painless, but we cannot afford to be soft. There will be problem areas that will have to be dealt with sensitively and carefully. We will have to manage changes in a way that more confidence will be generated along the way. Our track record in managing changes in the past has been recognised by many all over the world as exemplary and the resources that we have pooled over the years, especially our financial and human resources, should provide the confidence to succeed even though the challenges are more serious than what we have faced before. Social cohesion is critical and in the process of meeting the challenges, we will have to provide special provisions for those who find it hard to cope, mainly because of their education and age. And as we make progress, we will have to ensure that everyone, regardless of race, language or religion, will be able to seize the opportunities that emerge, especially when they have made the efforts to adapt and be relevant to the changes.

Column: 452



    Sir, over the past two days, many valuable comments and proposals were made by Members, particularly my PAP colleagues, including the need to provide more help to the local businesses and SMEs, cutting red tape, better information sharing of retraining and upgrading courses available for our workers, so that they are better able to consider available employment opportunities. I support these proposals.

    Sir, I would like to turn to some specific issues. First, employment opportunities for older or mature workers who have voiced their concerns about their employment difficulties. They pointed out that employers prefer younger workers, even though they have work experience and the required skills and qualifications. It is frustrating for them after they have conscientiously attended retraining or skills upgrading courses to face barriers to employment, even though they have realistic expectations of the job and compensation terms. With the changes in the CPF contribution rates for older workers, especially those in the 50 to 55 years age group, their wages would have been moderated. We will have to urgently change employers' mindsets to get them to give the older workers a fair opportunity to be employed. In the new work environment where companies have to constantly restructure to boost their competitiveness, workers will face more frequent employment changes. It will be very stressful for older workers in this new employment regime if the employers only prefer the younger workers. It is therefore necessary for the Government to address this issue urgently and to consider incentives to jolt employers' mindsets to be fair in providing employment opportunities to older workers who have gone for skills and knowledge upgrading to be relevant to the current demands of the workplace.

    Sir, next, complaints or allegations of discriminatory hiring practices. Sir, some job applicants have provided feedback at my meet-the-people sessions and some have also written to the press that they are discriminated when they apply for a job. They can understand that there are jobs which may require special requirements

Column: 453

and, if they do not meet the job requirements, for example, a language ability or, more specifically, the ability to speak Mandarin, or any other special skills, they will not be considered for the job. However, they feel very aggrieved when they consider themselves qualified based on the job specifications, but not considered for jobs for reasons which are not disclosed. They simply cannot understand their rejections.

    Sir, such grievances should be urgently addressed. Otherwise, there will be a loss of trust and confidence and our social cohesion will be severely tested. At this time of great uncertainty and increasing competition, we must strengthen our unity and pull together to become a formidable competitor.

    Sir, let me now touch on the sensitive issues of foreign talents. Some Singaporeans have also voiced their concerns of being displaced by foreign workers or talents. The ERC Report has recognised that bringing in foreign talent is a sensitive issue, especially so now in a slow economy with retrenchments and rising unemployment. However, we must be able to attract enough global talents in order to be a dynamic and competitive economy. There is, in fact, a great competition for global talents and it would be better for us to get them in our workforce than in our competitors' workforce. They can certainly help create more job opportunities for Singaporeans. Having said this, I think more needs to be done to explain to Singaporeans why it is vital for us to attract foreign or global talent to complement our workforce so that we are a world-class workforce able to sustain the attraction of good quality investments to Singapore.

    Sir, on the development of an entrepreneurial culture so that Singaporeans at all levels can be more enterprising and more self-reliant, I support the ERC's proposal to extend programmes to promote entrepreneurship to the young people through the Community Development Councils. Sir, allow me to share the experience at

Column: 454

the South East CDC. We are promoting a Young Entrepreneurs Programme. Last year, we organised a Breakthrough Camp for students to encourage them to break out of the mould and to acquire an entrepreneurial spirit. During the camp, the students were taught business skills emphasising creative as well as practical aspects. The students were challenged in a very short time to work a business proposal with limited resources, that is, simulating the real world. They presented their business ideas to a panel of "investors" and the successful projects went on to organise a Christmas Bazaar at the Marine Parade Promenade. Even the teams that were not selected were so fired up that they organised themselves as a marketing team to promote the Bazaar. They made a profit of over $6,000 which they unhesitantly donated to the Straits Times' School Pocket Fund showing that they were entrepreneurs with a heart.

    Sir, in the process, we also created a community in support of entrepreneurs as parents, teachers and members of the Marine Parade Merchants Association came out, despite a heavy downpour, to encourage the budding entrepreneurs. There is great interest among the young and we will certainly continue with programmes with the aim of developing a strong, young entrepreneur network in the South East District.

    Finally, Sir, I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance what will be the impact of an increase in oil prices and a long, protracted war in Iraq on our economy. Are we ready with a contingency plan in case of such an eventuality?

    Sir, I am confident that Singaporeans, our leaders, employers, businessmen and workers have what it takes to ride over our current problems and build a more robust and competitive economy. However, we have to watch the external environment closely and understand the developments and trends. We cannot afford to be soft and must proceed quickly to implement the ERC recommendations. We have to cast aside the old mindsets and firmly resolve to pull together to find new and better ways to earn a good living.

Column: 455



    Sir, on this note, I support the motion.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Mr Speaker, Sir, just like my colleagues and fellow Singaporeans, I am encouraged by the Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister, Mr Lee Hsien Loong's bold vision in steering Singaporeans in this dull time into a safer environment.

    Sir, the title of my speech is `Striking a Balance - Going Forward'. The Budget has many practical aspects to strengthen our Singaporeans' resolve. I shall be focusing on four aspects. They are strengthening the social compact, embracing a flexible future, restoring CPF for the senior workforce and university graduates in the School of Straight Talk.

    First, on strengthening the social compact. The crux of Budget 2003 is about remaking the individual spirit and soul of Singaporeans as we embark on a future of uncertainties. Ever true to its political philosophy of "a government of the people, for the people, by the people," Budget 2003 promises a place for every Singaporean who makes the effort in the new Singapore economy through the focused assistance of the Government and the support of the unions and employers.

    Focused assistance and support do not equate with freebies and Singaporeans must begin to take the incremental steps to self-reliance. Logic dictates that priorities must first go into strengthening the fundamentals and infrastructure for the New Economy. The big challenge ahead is how fast is the Government able to implement the many recommendations of the ERC which are supposed to revitalise the economy.

    Questions ahead of us include: are Singaporeans ready for the wheel of change? In doing so, how can the Government strike a balance to ensure that we do not leave behind those older ones who are unable to catch up? On the other hand, if we were to move too slowly, then how can we ensure that the needs of the younger cohort will be fulfilled?

    Sir, we must not forget that there will always be in our midst those who are not

Column: 456

capable of managing transition and also those who need to be given the booster to get themselves going. The spiritual surgery that Singaporeans are going through must be supported by rich social capital where we will have to invest the time and efforts to explain and educate the population on policy and directions taken by the Government.

    People must feel that there is trust, respect and compassion in the society that they live in. This is where the Government must be at the helm. I have had the opportunity of co-chairing one feedback session on the expectations for Budget 2003 and also speaking to various stakeowners of Singapore.

    Contrary to the newspaper reporting, I am happy to note that there was concern expressed for the needy poor who include the middle income group whose breadwinners have lost their jobs. Brought up in a culture of loans ranging from loans for homes to cars, to household goods, to credit cards, many have a string of financial commitments. Yes, they can downgrade and sell off even at a loss. The fact remains that they are out of a job and may be so for a long time to come especially for those aged 40 and above.

    Although there were calls for Government subsidies and grants, these were dignified calls. They were calls for targeted subsidies, grants and loans for a limited period to help the unemployed tide over their difficult time. I call these reasonable calls because we have, in our midst, social capital that has self-regard and empathy. They were not asking for freebies. Here, I join my fellow MPs before me to urge the Government to consider a portion of the CPF account for the purpose of granting loans to those retrenched and who need to tide over their difficulties.

    Sir, I was saddened by what I saw when I went for my house visit in the evening in Boon Lay. The electricity of two households was cut off. In one household, the children were seen straining their eyes doing their homework in the dim candlelight. In another household, a little girl was reading under the dim light of the corridor.

Column: 457



    Sir, the retrenched middle-income group has never been included in any form of Government financial assistance. With an increasing cohort of Singaporeans falling into this group, it is timely that we give them more attention. Out of the 18,000 or so retrenched, 7,000 comes from this cohort, and this is no small number. In the words of DPM Lee "we now live in a fundamentally changed world", it is therefore appropriate that Singaporeans should wear a new mindset. Of course, with this come adjustments to realities around us which include lowering our expectations.

    Singaporeans are a pragmatic lot and I trust that we have the social capital and qualities to will ourselves to do what we need to do to survive. Nonetheless, the Government must realise that there is a social compact with its people. This social compact is to deliver jobs and stability to the people of Singapore who, in return, give the votes to the Government.

    It is unlike the employment relationship that a corporation has with its employees. That employment relationship is a commercial contract and therefore, an enterprise can within reasonable limits of the contract terminate this commercial contract.

    Sir, social capital is not just focused on how we might increase the wealth of an individual and a country. Social capital is itself a form of wealth. Sure, our social connections can help us in business but feelings of connection and commensurate feelings of safety, comfort and support constitute important qualities of life. As we look for competitive ways to be competitive, the Government must develop this social compact with Singaporeans in the midst of severe cost cutting and job losses due to retrenchment. It is through building up this social capital that we can strengthen every Singaporean's resolve, and collectively forge a better and flexible future. Hence, the social compact of the Singapore Government with its people must strengthen during these times.

    This brings me to my second point on embracing a flexible future. To embrace

Column: 458

a flexible future, Singaporeans have to discard old practices and habits, even practices that might be considered sacred cows. Hence, both employers and employees need to adopt a new mindset and better ways of doing things. This includes flexi work arrangements, overtime payments, flexi compensation and other overtime arrangements.

    Two main domains of the flexi future that we can consider are the collective agreements and flexi work mindset. On collective agreements, employers and unions may even need to review the terms and conditions in the collective agreements so as to help employers better manage the manpower cost structure, including benefits. For instance, why should some collective agreements have fixed increments and benefits, especially in a volatile situation, where we have to lower costs to safeguard jobs? We may even need to shed `grandfather baggages' in the collective agreements. Why should such collective agreements be signed for a duration of three years? In such volatile times, there may be a need for us to put in place flexi arrangements to review high cost items and irrelevant conditions which are deemed inappropriate in a changed situation.

    As the Prime Minister has put it, there is no iron rice bowl. Today, it is about disposable styrofoam bowls. In driving productivity and cost competitiveness, early retirement and layoffs are just some of the options open to companies. Very often, the hidden costs come from `grandfather rights' in the form of shift and roster patterns and entrenched compensation and benefits in collective agreements. One may argue, "Well, collective agreements are negotiable documents. Go and bargain for the best deal." But we know that negotiations tidying up wastages arising from fixated items in collective agreements can be protracted. Therefore, a more convenient and expeditious way taken by most companies is to retrench or offer early retirement. It enables companies to turn around bottomline results quickly.

    In new economy thinking, clean wage ensures cost competitiveness for business

Column: 459

and saves jobs. Renewal of collective agreements traditionally cost companies anything from 3-5% increase to the payroll. Moreover, they can tie companies down for a good three years. Perhaps it is time to rethink the structure and purpose of a collective agreement in the new economy, just as the unions themselves have been evolving their role to be more relevant. So, instead of just massive layoffs or early retirement, perhaps we can substitute with smaller-scale layoffs and trim the `grandfather baggage' in the collective agreements. They can achieve similar outcomes. In fact, they can be neater. Newcomers to the company simply inherit the `grandfather rights.' So what happens is that whilst we weed off employees at one end, the other end continues to grow into the rigidity of the system. Cost, therefore, continues.

    Singaporeans are facing a very uncertain future, with a number of factors converging at the same time: the worst economic downturn since independence, structural unemployment, highest unemployment rate, poor fertility rates, threats of terrorists acts, and the looming Iraq war. Against this background, Singaporeans need to strengthen their resilience to overcome these challenges. We can do this by adopting a flexi and pro-active mindset.

    It used to be challenges that we had to contend with. Today, and in the future, we have to face uncertainties. While challenges spur us on with hope, uncertainties underscore an unpredictable future, which can turn hope into despondency. Here, the Government and grassroots leaders must step in to raise the confidence of Singaporeans and encourage them to plough on.

    The second domain is on flexi mindset. We will begin to see a workforce made up of economic gypsies simply because they have turned itinerant, so as to adjust to an increasingly complex and inconsistent business environment. Singaporeans must recognise that a flexi arrangement is an important source of competitive advantage for companies. Two noteworthy benefits observed by

Column: 460

companies with flexi arrangements are enhanced productivity and being nimble in different business environments.

    In the area of employment relations, we see new trends emerging. Companies are beginning to hire temporary part-time or contract workers. Today, some 37,000 people in Singapore are classified as `temporary or part-time employees'. This may be a small number compared to many other countries, but it is a 50% jump from the number recorded in 1998. In today's difficult times, a temporary job is always better than no job but, clearly, there are many issues to be considered. For example, companies may have to specially invest in training for their short-term or part-time employees so as to raise their productivity. Furthermore, while employees may be denied a coherent career structure, they are flexible, as they can move on to other companies requiring their services. Companies will be able to stay competitive with a flexible workforce.

    I urge Singaporeans to adopt a flexible mindset with regard to employment. Many of the jobs that have gone may never come back. Flexibility is a way of widening the potential labour market. In addition to short-term or part-time working, flexible work arrangements come in other forms. They can include job sharing, tele-working or working from home, besides contract work.

    The Sub-Committee of the ERC on Enhancing Human Capital has, in its recommendations, highlighted the need to grant companies the discretion to implement work schedules that are based on their actual strategic needs. In other words, organisations should be given greater freedom to implement flexible working practices, so as to better optimise their manpower resources.

    Sir, the success of a flexible future hinges on implementing a framework or guidelines to prevent malpractices, as well as engaging the HR fraternity. There was also a recommendation to review the present employment legislation, which often limits the implementation of

Column: 461

flexi work arrangements. As the Sub-Committee on Enhancing Human Capital has rightly noted, a flexi-work arrangement can only succeed if employers and employees are prepared to adapt to new practices. To ensure that malpractices do not take place, the Ministry of Manpower, together with the unions, employers and professional HR bodies, should put in place broad guidelines for implementation.

    The Ministry also highlighted the challenges posed as a consequence of `contingency workers'. Non-permanent workers, for example, are not automatically entitled to employee benefits, such as medical and insurance entitlements. One option currently under review is the introduction of medical benefits that are pegged to the number of hours worked in a month.

    Sir, at this point, I would like to declare that I am a HR practitioner as well as the President of SHRI, and what I am about to speak reflects the views of my profession and Institute.

    Sir, there are three areas that the HR fraternity would like to offer its services to promote a flexible culture in our industry. They are joint participation with the Tripartite Body, SBF as well as the newly set up CET statutory board and the CAL.

    The issues arising from implementing flexi collective agreements and work mindset will need to be addressed by the HR experts and practitioners from the HR fraternity. These credible professionals have years of practical experience and insights into issues of organisation and employment. No substitute can just spring out of the blue to resolve these issues. I say this because - although I am the Co-Chairperson of the Sub-Committee on Enhancing Human Capital - I only came to know that SBF and SPRING Singapore are poised to forge HR excellence and competencies when I saw the print in chapters 12 and 13 of the ERC report. On national programmes such as these, it is

Column: 462

important that the HR fraternity play a key role as well.

    Sir, it is heartening to note and hear from many quarters, including our highest political leadership, on the importance of human capital. As co-players, the HR fraternity sees itself as a plus component in the tripartite formula.

    Singapore has been re-making itself in every sphere in the last two years. Why not re-make the Tripartite Body into a Tripartite-Plus that will then see a more visible impact of the professionals in the decision making of the Tripartite Body? I am glad that the HR fraternity in the private sector, represented by the Ministry of Manpower as well and by SHRI, has been actively promoting and showcasing HR excellence and practices through a community of learning and sharing, both locally and overseas. As mentioned, the SBF will be setting up a HR Centre of Excellence to drive HR practices and excellence in the private sector. The HR fraternity sees itself synergising its practical experience and practices with the Centre. I see a twinning of the 38-year-old SHRI with the newborn HR Centre of Excellence of the SBF.

    Embracing a flexible future is to remain relevant with the skills and knowledge that will empower Singaporeans to stay employable, as well as to assume any form of self-employment activities. This entails every Singaporean to acquire multi-skills and lifelong learning capabilities. This is their only form of safety net to endure uncertainties in the environment. The establishment of a national Continuing Education and Training (CET) body and a Centre for Adult Learning (CAL), together with the setting up of portable training accounts for our workforce, will ensure that Singapore has the future workforce that is relevant to the needs of the industry. The ERC recommendations to equip Singaporeans for the future and to help Singaporeans to face up to the challenges are concrete steps to this flexible future.

    Sir, on restoring CPF for the senior workforce, the Minister for Finance, in his

Column: 463

Budget speech, announced that the restoration of the CPF rate to 20% will not take place over the next two years. Instead, the current 16% rate of employer's contribution will be retained over the next two years. The purport of this measure is to ensure that wage costs do not get out of line with the urgent priority of helping Singapore recover from this recession. Since wage costs represent a significant part of total costs in Singapore today, this move is indeed a signal to investors that this Government is serious about tackling the issue of cost competitiveness.

    However, Sir, there are a number of concerns that I would like to raise with respect to the issue of not restoring the 20% employer contribution rate for those who are 50 and above, even when this recession is well behind us. The main concern behind this policy is that older Singaporeans are able to find jobs in the future. Most of the concerns centre around the observation that employers perceive older workers to be more costly than their younger counterparts, and less productive as well.

    As a number of my colleagues have said so before, I think the Government would have a better time selling its case if it can back up the assumptions with solid data to show that older workers do not represent value for money, when compared to their younger counterparts. Is there data evidence to show that older workers are less productive and would cost more in terms of the value-add they bring to the job, as compared to younger workers? Are there real, concrete bits of information to conclusively demonstrate that the policy of maintaining the employer's CPF contribution rate at 16% would significantly reduce the overall costs of doing business in Singapore and, therefore, increasing the employability of older workers?

    The recent experience that this group of people could not gain re-employment after losing their jobs suggests that the problem of employability may have its cause elsewhere. If such is the case, then the policy of not restoring the employer's contribution to 20% for this group of

Column: 464

workers would be a double whammy blow for them. I think that it would be much more prudent to educate employers to change their perceptions concerning older workers rather than adopt a measure that may not be very effective to begin with.

    This is especially so when we think about the difficulties many among this group of workers would face in ensuring that they have sufficient funds for their retirement and not have to depend on the state for their upkeep. While it is laudable to attempt to maintain the employability of this group of workers, it is also important that we keep other objectives in mind before implementing the policy. This is especially so if we wish to ensure that many older workers do not suffer undue hardship in the years to come. Sir, I also join my colleagues in advocating for a mindset programme or campaign for employers with regard to employing the senior workforce.

    The fourth aspect is providing the university graduates a transit in the School of Straight Talk. I would like to urge those graduates who are still unemployed to take an active lifestyle during this time by tapping the services available at self-help groups, CDCs and SPEC.

    SPEC is termed the `School of Straight Talk' because it runs practical programmes that equip the retrenched participants with realities of a downturn, values and skills and assist them with job placements. Such pre-employment orientation talk in an unemployment situation can be useful. Bottom-line driven organisations are shunning university graduates for diploma holders and ITE graduands because these are supposed to be less demanding.

    In actual fact, many bottom-line driven organisations are taking this opportunity to recast jobs traditionally held by the `O' and `A' levels holders. Many of these jobs are now redesigned and enlarged for the diploma holders.

    In my opinion, the potential of the university graduates lies in their ability to

Column: 465

contribute at a higher strategic level. There will always be a need in this area.

    Nonetheless, if university graduates are prepared to start from the lowest end and win over the potential employer with a willing attitude, they can have an advantage in terms of their strategic contribution to the company in the long run. It can be very discouraging to be faced with a bleak job prospect and, at the same time, being told that their failure to find a job is because of their unrealistic expectations.

    Over FM 93.8 radio, graduates were interviewed on their feelings about the job market and many have expressed despondency over the bleak job prospect.

    Sir, I am concerned that if this matter is not given the attention, the morale of our university graduates and their resolve to find a job would be affected.

    The School of Straight Talk runs programmes on Entrepreneurship, Self-Employment and Minding the Mind in difficult times. Such programmes will help boost the confidence of our graduates, inculcate a flexible mindset and equip them with practical skills.

    I urge the Government to extend some financial assistance under the WSTP funding for retrenched workers to this group of graduates as well. In this way, they can prepare themselves better for the job that they are looking for. And so, university graduates need not despair whilst waiting for that job.

    Sir, in conclusion, I would like to raise that in our pursuit for unprecedented structural change, we must be mindful that our transactions and relationship with people do not evolve into an adversarial stance, where each hardens its resolve.

    What we do not need more are the quick fixes to problems within the rules in the box. Instead, we need strong social capital support for the stark choices arising from thinking out of the box.

Column: 466



    As people grapple in the dark to find new ways, they want and need help. Such help must be based on respect, trust and advocacy of interests within the context of evolving new lives for Singaporeans.

    Sir, Budget 2003 will spur the implementation of the ERC recommendations and the success lies in the acceptance of a flexi future by the public, private and people sectors of Singapore. Only then can the economy remain competitive for years to come.

    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to focus on two groups, the older Singaporeans and young Singaporeans: what do they have to look forward to?

    First, older Singaporeans. In this debate, much has been said about the problems posed by our aging workforce, such as increased social spending in the future. The answer to this problem, as stated in the Budget Statement, is: we must find new sources of growth or else stagnate and decline. Put this way, the aging population is cast as a burden on society and the cause of possible stagnation. Why not view them instead as a potential engine for economic growth? The greying population can be a big opportunity for business and can spur the Silver Sector, the industry for senior citizens. This would involve not only medical and nursing care, but also creating, producing and marketing products and services to meet their changing needs and interests. This would include anti-aging healthcare and beauty products, health supplements like Viagra, cheaper and better alternatives to that, as well as leisure activities. The Silver Sector may also boost the pension and insurance industries.

    Just look at the phenomenon of line dancing which took our older Singaporeans by storm. Imagine how much money some entrepreneurs made by selling cowboy boots, cowboy hats and chequered shirts. Mind you, these are not cheap stuff. As I understand it, the cowboy boots are brought in from Australia and

Column: 467

they cost from $100 to $1,000 a pair and they are being snapped up by our not-so-young residents and during an economic downturn. Sir, we should not keep painting all older Singaporeans as people without spending power and who would only drain our resources.

    Sir, in 10 years, we will have more empty nesters than young people. Empty nesters are those aged 40 to 59, with their youngest nearing financial independence. We will also have more aging singles with considerable purchasing power. The number of empty nesters is forecast to grow by 50% to 10.9 million during the next decade in economies like Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan. At the same time, the youth market will shrink by 10% during the same decade. In Japan, some companies are already reorienting their marketing to appeal to the senior citizens. As the Asian Wall Street Journal reported on February 28th, Yamaha Corp had two years ago created an easy to play electronic guitar for older people who grew up on the Beatles and Japanese folk rock and who had always wanted to play the guitar. So they produced an easier version of the electronic guitar. The guitar was a hit with those above 50 and they were all snapped up.

    There is another reason why the Government should nurture the Silver Sector as one of our new growth industries. It would also help with the employment situation of our older workers. Studies in other countries show that companies with customers aged over 45 are more likely to employ a mature worker. These companies know that if they are to appeal to mature customers, they need to improve the level of service they offer this group. Older workers will become increasingly important in developing relationships with customers.

    Our growing population would also influence employment trends. In Australia, the second biggest employer group was hospitals and nursing homes with about 330,000 workers. As its population gets older and begins to require even more medical attention, employment categories such as medical and dental services are

Column: 468

expected to continue to grow. This means more jobs would be created in these sectors. Are we projecting for this?

    Sir, many of our older workers today feel that their future in Singapore looks like a bleak one because what they hear and see is this: their pay needs to be cut year after year by the CPF to make them more employable and then jobs are still hard to come by even with the CPF cuts. Cost will keep rising as public services become more market-oriented. Medical and social services will be means-tested. They are a burden to society. The emphasis is on nurturing the young, and not the old.

    Sir, we need to get through to them a better vision of their future - or else why should they buy into it? That is why one of the brightest spots in this year's Budget to me is the setting up of a new statutory board for Continuing Education and Training. It should tailor programmes specifically for our mature workers which can then place them into decent jobs. If the pay is too low with reduced CPF and the job is too onerous, older workers may not see it as worth their while to carry on working. One way to encourage them to continue working is to provide financial incentives.

    Sir, under one proposal in Australia, people who work for five years beyond their pension age could become eligible for a tax-free payment of A$25,000 when they retire. We need not be so generous. But the option to me seems stark - unemployed and pessimistic older workers clamouring for more handouts and subsidies or older workers with decent jobs which make them feel useful and wanted, and a decent quality of life to make them glad that they are Singaporeans.

    Turning to young Singaporeans, Sir, their mood today is one of frustration and despondency. Many of our fresh graduates have found it hard to get the jobs they want. But it is useful to remember that this is not the first time that we have been through such a difficult time. Indeed, when I graduated in 1986, it was a recession year and I too found it hard to

Column: 469

find a job. After my final examinations, jobs were so scarce that I had to take a part-time job, telling children stories at the Robinson's toy department. I was hired by a young entrepreneur who was bringing in teddy bears from Australia, and for each bear, there was a character in the story. So I gained from the efforts of a young entrepreneur. My pay was $100 a week as my job was only over the weekends in the afternoons in the toy department. That was about $400 a month. But the money managed to tide me over for about two months until I got a full-time job at $800 a month. So that was double - what joy! And that was as an editor-cum-writer-cum-sales-cum-marketing person-cum-ad-copywriter-cum many other small jobs for a small time publication company. It was an insecure job because the company's finances were shaky.

    But despite the poor prospects, I thought having a job was much better than having none. And frankly, I had a great time because I felt stretched and I also learnt to stretch the dollar. And one of the greatest pleasures for me in those days was to save up enough to have breakfast at McDonald's. But about five months later in August 1986, I got a job in the Straits Times which was the start of a more stable career until I joined politics in 2001. I tell this story to remind ourselves that this gloomy situation for our young graduates is only temporary. The crucial thing I learn is to keep our chins up and to seize every opportunity that comes.

    I see this tough time as an opportunity for our young Singaporeans to show their mettle. The more entrepreneurial among us should strike out and follow their passion. What is the worst that could happen? We fail, so what? Try again, better than staring at the wall and griping. And with the Minister of State in charge of entrepreneurship, the outlook should be more promising now.

    The more creative among us should write plays, poems, songs, make movies that can give us a different view of things

Column: 470

and, in the process, help lift us from this gloom. In this respect, I am pleased that the Government is not stinging on its investment in the arts scene.

    I am not sure how many of you remember but there is this song titled "Happy Days are Here Again". It was written in 1929 in the US for a movie called "Chasing Rainbows" and the chorus goes:

    Happy days are here again.

    The skies above are clear again.

    So let us sing a song of cheer again.

    Happy days are here again.

    Sir, this song was written and sung in the midst of the Great Depression in the US. Yet the lyrics are one of hope and cheer. You have to hear the Barbara Streisand version to hear how exhilarating the song can be. What we are going through is by no means a great depression, but where we are heading towards is indeed a great destination.

    The Budget is a step towards realising the vision of a leading global city, a hub of talent, enterprise and innovation and one of the best places to work and live in Asia. It is a place where, young or old, all of us can enjoy an interesting and fulfilling life. This is something that we should look forward to and work towards.

    Sir, in conclusion, we have many strengths, not least a team of good leaders who have brought us this far. It must be recalled that, though some of the changes in recent years have been swift and drastic, such shifts are not new in Singapore. The 1960s, in fact, had been the most revolutionary for Singapore. Few other countries have undergone so many significant changes in so short a period. The 1960s saw the transition of Singapore from a colony to an internally self-governing state from 1959 to 1963, to becoming a part of the Federation of Malaysia from 1963 to 1965, and then to an independent republic. Furthermore, the challenges that threaten Singapore's economic viability as a state was sprung

Column: 471

on it in quick succession. This includes Sukarno's Confrontation and Britain's decision to withdraw its military bases in 1975 which left Singapore with the task of absorbing 40,000 employees, making up for the loss of 20% of the GNP and creating a credible defence force within four years. It was Singapore's leadership, together with the support of the people, that effectively overcame all these severe problems.

    Sir, in 1986, when I was wondering what the future held, there was a team looking at how to pull Singapore out of the recession. It was called the Economic Committee and was led by Mr Lee Hsien Loong, then Minister of State for Trade and Industry. Today we have another committee, the Economic Review Committee, led also by Mr Lee. Sir, I would say that our leaders have had a good track record so far. This should give our people confidence. I, for one, am confident that, with the people united behind the Government, determined to achieve a better Singapore, happy days would indeed be here again.

    On that note, I support the motion.

    Mr Chay Wai Chuen (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I just want to speak in support of this motion in the name of the Minister for Finance. Members of the House have been speaking and have spoken at length on the various issues in the Economic Review Committee Report on entrepreneurship and the present economic difficulties we are facing. I want to focus specifically on the investment issues and business related issues to growth.

    First, on the foreign direct investment issue. Our economic strategy over the past three decades or more has been on attracting foreign investments that will lead to growth and employment. We had been very fortunate. We embarked on this path in the sixties, just about the time when the MNCs were going transnational. We betted on the MNCs and the export growth strategy and that would help us clear our unemployment problem then and our growth into the future. We were right.

Column: 472



    Today, however, the other giants have awakened, chiefly India and China. And, today we all know China is absorbing the major share of the FDIs from the world.
