To many, this seems like a triple whammy! Many workers have neither the skills, resource nor mindset to do so. Sir, to lessen the shock and pain felt by some of our workers, I advocate the setting up of a proper job transition mechanism using a holistic approach. Perhaps under the new CET Institute to be set up under the Ministry of Manpower, retrenched workers can receive advice and counselling that is beyond simple job matching. We can assist displaced workers by a four-step process:

    First, give them emotional counselling, so that they are better able to absorb the retrenchment news;

    Second, give them financial counselling, so that they can better manage their

Column: 508

living expenses and better deploy their retrenchment benefits;

    Third, retrain them or job match them, so that they can have a meaningful placement; and

    Fourth, for those who desire to venture into entrepreneurship, they could be redirected to an entrepreneurship agency, so that they can learn to better assess and manage their risk. Mentorship programmes can be encouraged and access to business networks, opportunities and infrastructure could also be facilitated indiscriminately. In other words, whether the entrepreneurial activity is in the low-tech, high-tech or no-tech industry, the desired outcome is to get our people to adopt a different mindset - a mindset to carve out a niche for themselves to stay nimble and be self-reliant, a mindset to embrace risk as part of their daily staple.

    On CPF. Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the policy on the temporary freeze on CPF restoration for two years. However, I hope that employers who are doing well will reward their employees and put back some of these CPF reductions to their salary either in the form of monthly variable component or even yearly bonus. This would augur well for long-term employer/employee relationship. Perhaps the civil service may want to lead by example.

    The CPF scheme is a sacred cow not to be slaughtered. Started in 1955 as a simple retirement savings scheme, it is a scheme that encourages the virtues of work and thrift, and saving for rainy days. The scheme's sole purpose was that of nestegg accumulation, so that members can be self-reliant when their income stops. Today, the CPF scheme has evolved into a multi-layer and multi-purpose scheme which not only confuses some, but no longer a reliable nestegg for many.

    In good financial planning practice, it is important to earmark specific resource for a specific goal. Otherwise, the multi-use of a resource with separate goals can lead to conflict, confusion and an intertwined web of different objectives. Sir, a slave of many

Column: 509

masters faces multiple duties, obligations and functional woes. This, to me, appears to be the dilemma faced by our CPF scheme. Over the years, this simple compulsory savings scheme has come to mean different things to different people. As much as it is a life-line for retirees, home owners and investors, it is also a source of lifeblood for some of Singapore's economic initiatives. This is evident in industries where CPF funds can be channelled into. Clearly, in the residential property market and, to a lesser extent, the financial market, each relaxation of the CPF rules, from 1980s to 1990s, to allow for more funds released into the respective industry, never fails to fuel the industry.

    According to the Department of Statistics, $119 billion was poured into housing over the last 10 years while $12.5 billion was withdrawn from CPF in the year 2000. And where did it go? Into housing. If this is not evident enough of our obsession with property, a 2001 paper by the Wharton-SMU Research Centre showed that the average Singaporean has 75% of his assets locked into housing, compared with 20% in the USA. What then is left for retirement? Answer: a big house, small cash, and perhaps arrears in payment. Perhaps the Government can set up a study group to examine ways to help Singaporeans unlock the value of their property to encourage self-sufficiency.

    As in the case of property, but perhaps to a lesser extent, the financial market boomed as millions of dollars were poured into the CPF-approved financial instruments. All these would have been good news, except that the starry eyes that went in came out tearing, as the volatility in these investments proved too much to stomach.

    The consequence of such a development, if unchecked, will result in an urgent call for a bigger provision for social security measures, either through forward financing - meaning we have got to pay more tax today - or a burden on the next generation of taxpayers, and more deficit

Column: 510

budgeting in the years to come. All these are undesirable.

    What is the alternative? I think the move by the Government to relook and realign the CPF scheme is a wise one, but one which needs to be done at an accelerated pace and more decisively. I have four basic suggestions:

    First, on the retirement fund. CPF should stay true to its original objective of providing a nestegg for its members. This should remain the primary and single most important objective. In the original scheme of things, assuming that an average couple earns an average annual income of $50,000 per year, and works for 35 years, at the original contribution rate of 40% and an interest rate of 2.5% per annum, they would have accumulated a nestegg of more than $1 million in their CPF. In other words, almost every other Singaporean household could be a millionaire household when they retire! But this could be history. With CPF funds pouring into property and half-understood investments, it was reported that most Singaporeans would not even be able to meet the Minimum Sum when they retire. Therefore, bolder steps to move cash into the retirement account should be advocated with urgency.

    The Special and Retirement Accounts' interest rate of 4% per annum is highly attractive and, in fact, generous in such times. Could the Government use this as an incentive to incentivise members to voluntarily contribute additional funds in the above accounts? Could cash also be accepted? Could there be further tax relief for those who bite? Obviously, members would have to reckon that such voluntary contributions can only be withdrawn at retirement age. The current recommendation of a moderate increase to the retirement account is too little, too late. This could be a one-time exercise or a long-term strategy if the Government can afford it. Ultimately, it is either we encourage self-funding or state funding.

    Second, on investment account. Investment via the CPF scheme should be properly missioned and managed. It is

Column: 511

a nestegg and should be treated as such. While there is nothing wrong with advocating self-investment, the assumption must be that all CPF members comprehend the principles and tools of investment. But is this a reasonable assumption? I do not think so. Most investors who make use of the CPFIS are, in fact, first-time investors. Like fire, this resource is useful to those who know its risk and learn how to use it. Like fire, it is dangerous and damaging to those who are ignorant. Many CPF members saw it not so much as a way to grow their nestegg, but a way to make some money and cash out immediately from the profits. Alas, the fire proved too hot for handling and many got their nestegg burnt. They got barbecued egg in burnt nest instead. While some may be wiser after losing their money, many remain confused and put the blame on CPF or friends who have advocated the investment. We need to do more to help Singaporeans wise up in the world of financial management. It is not rocket science, but it is no ABC either. I have advocated many times in this House, that financial literacy should be made a priority to increase the financial quotient (or FQ) of Singaporeans, so that we can cope with the ever complex world of investment, and the urgency of retirement funding.

    Next, let me move on to the home purchase fund. The CPF Board also calls the CPF scheme a `home ownership fund'. But is this really so? Upon closer examination, it looks definitely more like a `house purchase fund' or a `property purchase fund'. Let me explain the difference. While a home purchase fund would focus more on the roof over the head for a household, a house purchase fund works like a property investment fund, where a basic roof is not the purpose, but the profit of the purchase becomes the primary objective. This is, in fact, the single most important fuel that fired up the property boom up until 15th May 1996, when the capital gains tax was imposed on property purchase. This is one way to place greater restraint on fund use. CPF as a `home purchase fund" is fine; but as a `house purchase fund' or a

Column: 512

property investment fund, there will be no end to the property chase.

    Next, on the Medisave fund. In the past, emperors and sages feared living too short a life. Today, many people fear living too long. The concerns of healthy living and illness funding are frequently heard. In fact, market talk has it that it is better to die than to fall sick in Singapore, due to high medical cost, amongst other things. Hence, I applaud the Government's helping hand in introducing and encouraging various medical and long-term care schemes like ElderShield, MediShield and, most recently, the portable medical benefit schemes. Knowing full well that there can only be limited success if left to market forces of demand and supply, the decision to make premiums payable via the Medisave scheme is a brilliant move. But more can be done. Here, I would like to support Mr Yeo Guat Kwang's call to widen the scheme. But in addition to the suggestions he has made, I have also been told that many Singaporeans are contracting one form of critical illness or another at a younger and younger age. As such, critical illness insurance premium is indeed amongst the most expensive forms of insurance, and it could be argued as probably one of the most important forms of insurance. Why? Because people do not necessarily die from it, but it will certainly make them a lot poorer. Critical illness does not work the same way as medical benefits which are indemnity schemes. Critical illness policies pay a lump sum upon diagnosis of a critical illness. Hence, I propose that the Government seriously consider setting up a national critical illness cover or allow critical illness policies to be purchased via the Medisave. This way, the drawdown on a person's limited resources could be better managed.

    Next, after we have talked about the people sector, I would like to move on to the private sector. Perhaps, in my opinion, the single biggest group that will benefit from this Budget is the SMEs. The Budget is consistent with the Government's effort to proactively develop a higher level of entrepreneurial activity in Singapore. But perhaps we should take a reality check

Column: 513

and ask: where are we now? Over the years, various international rating agencies have consistently rated Singapore highly for its infrastructure and pro-business environment. Yet in the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor Report 2001, published by the London School of Business and Babson College, Singapore was cited to be having one of the lowest rates of entrepreneurial activity in the 29 countries surveyed. There seems to be a disconnect somewhere. Have we created an environment where it favours foreign investors and GLCs over local SMEs? Or is it that the rewards of labour far outweigh the risk of entrepreneurship? In short, have we inadvertently become a victim of our own success?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in any economy, there are essentially four factors of production - land, labour, capital and entrepreneurship. In Singapore, the risk reward ratios of these four factors are out of balance. The rewards for land and labour far outweigh that of entrepreneurs, thereby creating disincentives to entrepreneurship. We will need to re-balance the equation to make entrepreneurship an attractive career option. As long as reward ratios are out of balance, then it is going to be difficult and an uphill struggle for us to encourage entrepreneurship. Access to capital could also be improved, especially for start-ups and those in the emerging and expansionary phases of growth.

    At the end of the day, businesses move to where there are more business opportunities and where money can be made. Yes, Singapore does not have a hinterland as in the case of Hong Kong and China, but our `hinterland' is located within the seven-hour flight radius, facilitated by high-tech connections and the successful Free Trade Agreements and bilateral trade and business agreements concluded. Thanks to the hard work and vision of MTI, we have cause for celebration, and opportunities await at our doorstep. It is now up to the Government to spread the good news, and the entrepreneurs to spread their wings.

Column: 514



    Finally, on the public sector. It is heartening to note in the Finance Minister's Budget Statement that the public sector will continue to simplify its rules and procedures and cut red tape. However, it is not just the rules and red tape that need pruning, but the necessity to urgently cultivate a pro-business, pro-customer service culture as we move forward. Obviously, deciding to transform is easy, but implementing it is difficult. The policymakers may have the will but the civil service must be prepared to `stick their necks out', stand on the side of business to understand the desired outcomes sought by the policymakers, and not get trapped in the process of things.

    As our civil service grows, the expanding midriff and layering distance the policymakers from the customers, and response time could be slowed. Many business and ordinary folks have been frustrated with standard replies and follow-the-rule-book attitude. Playing it safe becomes the name of the game, as no one wants to be held accountable for their actions. Hence, I applaud the setting up of the ministerial committee on the service industry, headed by Deputy Prime Minister Lee, and the ministerial committee on entrepreneurship under Minister of State Raymond Lim. This will bring both decision makers closer to the ground, provided that the structure is kept lean.

    Sir, in the past two days in this House, we have consumed western medicine, eastern medicine, psychotherapy as well as physiotherapy. Are we now ready to give birth? Sir, I believe that when the mind speaks, the body listens. The challenge is whether we can connect our mind (which is our leaders) to our body (which is our people), so that we can walk the talk as a nation. Our mind needs a loud and clear vision, so that our body will align itself to the purpose. Our people need a mental picture. If I could pose this question to our Finance Minister, if you have a piece of clean canvas today, what would be the picture that you would paint on it?

    We have no tradition in demonstrations, but we have a good track record in

Column: 515

campaigns, which have helped built our nation. I hope that in the next few months, campaigns depicting our visions and goals, best done in pictorial forms, could be launched as a marketing effort to align our mind and body. Ultimately, we do not want visions embossed on paper, but we want visions embodied in the daily lives of every resident in Singapore. Together, we stand; divided we kang-kor, meaning we fall.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is an old Chinese proverb that says `we cannot help the birds of sadness flying over our heads, but we need not let them build nests in our hair'. In fact, if we look beyond, there is a silver lining, and there is blue sky. We have a lot more sources and network than that of our forefathers who came from afar. As we stand at the crossroad of our third phase of growth, let us emulate the undying spirit of our founding fathers to be industrious, to be frugal, and, most of all, to be hopeful.

    Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Arthur Fong (West Coast): Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir, for allowing me to join in the debate.

    Sir, since the release of the ERC Report, there has been much debate on the means through which we can improve the competitiveness of Singapore in this fast changing global economy. We have talked about how we should remake Singapore, and have drafted plans to restructure our economy, to make our education system more responsive to the demands of the economy and to innovate in ways that will sustain development and wealth generation for all Singaporeans.

    Indeed, we have seen some of these imperatives of economic restructuring being put in place through last year's Budget. And in this year's Budget, delivered on 28th February by the Minister for Finance, we see more initiatives, vital to our survival, which are recommended by the ERC, being implemented.

    Sir, aside from the wealth of quality ideas from the various stakeholders from

Column: 516

all quarters, an able Government and a dependable infrastructure to execute the well-crafted grand plans, the people of Singapore must play their part.

    The economic slowdown and the threat of terrorism have cast a gloom on our people. It has put an austere mood over many a Singaporean. While it is a good thing to be austere and to revere the virtues of frugality, as Senior Minister of State, Mr Khaw, spoke about yesterday, in such times, the flip side is a dip in our morale. I want to speak on the ways in which we can improve the morale of Singaporeans in these hard times.

    We need to quickly adopt a double-barrel approach. We already have one barrel pinned down quite well, and that is, the ERC's recommendations are refreshing and hold promise. I would like to make some comments on the practical examples of the forward-looking character of our growth strategy.

    Singapore has taken further initiatives in the field of wealth management. These build on those initiatives announced last year. Singapore recognises that we need to position ourselves to provide these kinds of wealth management services to successful families. Singapore is well suited to deliver such services at a high level. There is competition, but the competitors do not have the advantages that Singapore has. Among the advantages are our sound banking and financial regulatory system.

    Presently, too much of the wealth management service industry, undertaken globally, is shrouded in secrecy. There is already a drive for change as advocated by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and other financial sector watchdogs. Singapore must be a first mover. There is an opportunity to take advantage of a significant shift in an industry that will learn to depend on service levels and confidentiality, rather than on secrecy. Singapore is uniquely placed to take advantage of this opportunity. We have developed into one of the top tier financial services

Column: 517

centres in Asia. The infrastructure is basically in place.

    To pre-empt or address any concerns on the standards applied in Singapore, we must put a supervisory framework in place. Some Members have, over the last two days, talked about the Singapore brand. The supervisory framework will safeguard our reputation as a Wealth Management Centre Par Excellence. This framework will respect the confidentiality of the clients of the service providers while ensuring that those service providers fully understand their clients, and the source of funds being managed.

    Singapore is noted, among financial watchdogs, for taking a tough stand in areas of money-laundering. This reputation will be a plus to develop Singapore to be a pre-eminent financial centre. This supervision is best done by way of a cooperative effort and could be spearheaded by the MAS. Respect for confidentiality might also lead to a desire to enact provisions for trusts that mirror those of banking information. That would further demonstrate our seriousness with which Singapore banks, financial and wealth management institutions treat their clients' information.

    The current changes to the trust provisions, which were announced in the most recent Budget, clarify certain areas so that one avoids ambiguity. In fact, something of a non-NUTS approach is evident in the ERC. An exclusion list of what cannot be done is proposed and anything outside that list is a green light. This will spur the creative and innovative culture we have been lamenting that is so lacking or subdued. The current changes have also expanded the availability of the benefits to foreign trusts managed by all trust companies in Singapore, details of which can be found in the Budget Statement.

    As the Minister mentioned, one other component that will be put in place soon is the review of legislation. This will bring the statutes current. This was recently done in relation to the companies

Column: 518

legislation. Now it is the turn of the trust legislation.

    We need to create an environment where the fiduciary service providers want to locate to Singapore. This is high value work. We will see the concept of clusters at work here. Significantly, ancillary services would flow from the development of wealth management services in Singapore. Legal services, banking services, financial management, financial planning and private banking are all services that depend heavily on the skills and abilities of the persons supplying these services. These services are skill-intensive and require a high level of understanding and some experience. We will see a magnet for talent flow from this. In addition, the information technology requirements are very sophisticated and the development of information systems can provide an opportunity to service the industry worldwide. Best practices are evolving in this area as well. An opportunity exists here. Skilful and hardworking people are providing conscientious service to global clients. This is a recipe for success that augurs well for Singapore's plan to be a pre-eminent financial centre.

    I spoke of taking a double-barrel approach. It is clear from my elaboration of the wealth management area, addressed by the ERC, that we have one barrel fully loaded and armed. Let us consider the other barrel. The other barrel should be loaded with a call to Singaporeans to rise to the challenge we face. Government leaders, while persisting in encouraging changing mindsets of Singaporeans, must also continue to reassure Singaporeans that we will have our day in the sun.

    Sir, just like in banking, when a client's investment portfolio is down as a result of market action, bankers will, along with working out strategies, also handhold their clients through a difficult period. In so doing, it will allow continued focus on the longer term investment objectives and avoid hasty knee-jerk reactions.

    Sir, while we want individuals to be more self-reliant, we must ensure that the

Column: 519

fighting spirit of Singaporeans cannot and must not wane. Singaporeans cannot be pessimistic. We cannot let our energies ebb.

    Singaporeans have to recognise whatever creative effort and energy that are present in us, and draw on them. We cannot lose the sense of urgency to move on. Singaporeans must see this. I think in this area, Government leaders must do more cheer leading along with their grand plans. Without a high morale, we will find ourselves at the bottom of the cliff and without voice. Then, we cannot say we have a great this or a great that, or we are ranked this or that, or how clean and green our city is. For we will no longer be any of these, but a nation of pessimists doomed to fail. Investors will not come to our shores and people will leave once the people of Singapore lose their drive and desire to succeed, most of all, the guts to try and try again.

    Sir, the morale of our people must be high. The Government has the leadership quality, the resolve and experience to tip the morale scales in Singapore's favour. The ERC Report is just one of the avenues, or tool kits, to address and pre-empt the challenges we are facing and will encounter in the near and foreseeable future.

    The Government has always been upfront and direct about the problems we have. We acknowledge what and where the problems are. In this respect, we need to reassure Singaporeans that we will ride the challenges and come out with our heads high, just as we did in the 1970s.

    I was encouraged and felt a sense of pride as I read in the Sunday Times' report on the four Singaporeans who ventured to India. Their indomitable spirit to succeed and try something new came through clearly. Sir, we need to hear and see more of such instances of a fighting spirit. We need to celebrate and give cheer to such instances of entrepreneurship and pioneering spirit. As our Prime Minister so succinctly put it - we should philosophise and see how things are not all bad.

Column: 520



    Let us look at the Finns and see how they dealt with a dramatic upheaval in their economic environment. Up until the early 1990s, Finland had been part of the Eastern bloc and went unnoticed in the global economy. With the collapse of the Soviet Union, Finland's economy underwent a major transformation. Practically overnight, it lost a quarter of its major export market. This resulted in massive unemployment in many sectors of the Finnish economy. However, despite this economic hardship, the Finnish people did not despair. The Finnish Parliament agreed that its government should invest heavily in education and research. These investments paid off. Today, 10 years after the crisis, Finland is the world's most competitive economy, according to a ranking by the World Economic Forum. Average economic growth since 1994 has been 5%, and this is significant for an industrialised country.

    It is ironic that it took a serious economic crisis for Finland to realise its potential. We have the benefit of a strong open market economy that has stood us in good stead for many years. But given the success of previous years, Singaporeans were not prepared for this sustained downturn. It was a shock to the system.

    Like the Finns, Singaporeans need to be flexible, innovative and turn a deep adversity into a grand challenge. Unity of purpose across the sectors and interests, and planning with perspective even in the midst of a crisis are important. Look at the Finns and the remarkable Nokia their people have created. Singapore is geared in the same way.

    Sir, we need to raise the morale of Singaporeans. As Mark Twain once said, "There is nothing sadder than a young pessimist." We cannot be a young nation of pessimists, if what the ERC recommendations and the implementation of such imperatives are anything to go by. There is much hope. Yes, we are facing serious challenges in the economic downturn. However, we must make all efforts to ensure that Singaporeans do not lose heart. If that happens, then no amount of

Column: 521

remaking will help us get to where we need to be in the New Economy of a changed world.

    Sir, we have the brains, we have the passion and the will. But we need to have a heart and the guts to move forward.

Column: 521

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Debate resumed.
3.42 pm

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, this Budget is an important step forward in restructuring our economy. It builds on the strategic shifts which we began last year, especially the tax changes, the offset package for the tax changes, including the ERS distributed on 1st January, and also the CPF changes. So, as aptly pointed out by Ms Indranee Rajah and other MPs, the measures and policies in this Budget should be seen in that context, and not in isolation.

    The Budget will also have to be seen in the context of the current global outlook, and the short-term prospects for the Singapore economy. The global outlook is very uncertain. Much hinges on what will happen in Iraq. The whole world is now anxiously following developments at the UN Security Council, watching to see if war breaks out over the next few days and, if there is a war, how events develop and what happens afterwards.

    One significant question is which way oil prices will move. Oil prices are already very high, both in anticipation of the

Column: 522

war disrupting supplies and also because problems in Venezuela have already reduced supplies. Analysts are not optimistic that oil prices will fall rapidly, as happened after the Gulf War in 1991. If oil prices stay high, it will dampen the global economy.

    From the US economy, the recent signs have been mixed. The consensus is still that we can expect a modest US recovery in the second half of the year and that, as a whole, 2003 should be slightly better than 2002. But this is not at all a sure thing. Some well-respected analysts are worried about the US economy, particularly Steve Roach of Morgan Stanley. They fear that high oil prices, high consumer debt, deflation and the lingering hangover of the burst dot-com bubble will result in another US recession. Since Europe and Japan remain weak, a US recession would leave the whole world without any engine of growth.

    This is still a minority view, but it is one that we have to take seriously. I met one experienced US analyst recently and he told me that in more than 20 years he had never seen a time like this, where people were so uncertain as to which way the US economy was heading and market analysts were so divided in their views. And, therefore, he was very worried.

    Despite these dark clouds on the horizon, right now, our own economy is still growing. We had 2.2% GDP growth last year and the unemployment rate improved somewhat to 4.2% at the end of the year, coming off from its peak of 4.6%. So far, this year, the signs have been positive. For January, our non-oil domestic exports increased by 18% year on year and our industrial production manufacturing output also went up 14% year on year. The early indications are that the first quarter GDP growth is quite steady. Our early estimate, based mainly on January data, is plus 2.7%. And this is despite the major uncertainty of war hanging over the global economy.

    Therefore, I think Dr Wang Kai Yuen may have been a little bit too pessimistic when he said that the worst is yet to

Column: 523

come. But it is certainly possible that things can get worse and we will need to monitor and assess developments closely, and be prepared if this happens.

    The main concern among many Singaporeans is jobs. Many people have said this is a pro-business budget. But, as Mdm Halimah Yacob and Mr Matthias Yao have pointed out, in fact, this is a pro-jobs, pro-growth and pro-worker Budget. The Budget aims at preserving existing jobs and creating new and better jobs for our people. But all the budget measures are only enablers, because success lies in our people seeing, creating and seizing the opportunities that come our way.

    In the immediate term, reducing costs is important. But, ultimately, to create more jobs, we need to look for new businesses and create new value. We are making major strategic shifts, and we must get them right and implement the changes speedily.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang complained that the cost of living is very high. If I may borrow a phrase from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, he is a very good storyteller. In fact, last year, the consumer price index fell by 0.4%, despite the public transport fare increase. Many basic food items cost less, like rice, cooking oil, meat, seafood and vegetables. Housing cost 2.2% less, because of electricity tariffs coming down, accommodation and household durables becoming cheaper. Transport and communication costs fell by 1%, because of cheaper petrol and the lower road tax. Only healthcare and education costs rose marginally.

    While the CPI fell, nominal wages went up by about 1% last year. Mr Steve Chia asked for a 30% cut in Ministers' salaries. How will this solve our problem? If it is to be a symbolic gesture, then we had already done it in November 2001, when we cut monthly salaries of Ministers by 10%. And, if we take it together with cuts in annual payments, in fact, the result was an overall reduction of 20% in annual remuneration. Last November we extended the cut for another 12 months till December 2003.

Column: 524



    Several Members, such as Dr Warren Lee and Dr Teo Ho Pin, have asked for more help to be given to the lower income group. This we will do. The Government has already implemented substantial measures to help all Singaporeans in this year's and last year's budgets, specially focused on the lower income group. We are providing additional help where it means the most, in basic household expenditure items, such as utilities and Service & Conservancy (S&C) charges. The Government extended the Utilities Save scheme by one year, and granted an extra month of rebates on S&C charges for all 1- to 5-room HDB flats. So, come April, all the flats will be spared S&C charges. And these are over and above the previous provisions. Also, we should not forget that by staggering the GST increase into two steps, we have effectively given Singaporeans a very large rebate this year of $650 million.

    Mr Ahmad Khalis, Dr Warren Lee and Mdm Ho Geok Choo also spoke on maintaining the social fabric and providing additional help to those who cannot pay utilities bills. We will do that. However, we should keep the lines of responsibility clear. Power Supply is not a welfare organisation. Its bills have to be paid. But people who need help paying these bills should try to get help from the CDCs and CCCs, where ample help is available. We will have to depend on the grassroots leaders to distinguish between those in genuine need and those who can help themselves to be more self-reliant. With their assessment, with their sensitive management, where there is discrimination, we can deliver the help where it is most needed, without discouraging a lot of other people from working and looking after themselves.

    Several Members, including Mr Inderjit Singh, Mr Iswaran and Mdm Cynthia Phua, have said that the middle income group's concerns have not been addressed. I think they are mistaken. Rightly, we have focused our help on the lower income group. However, we have also implemented measures for the middle income group. The Utilities Save and the S&CC rebates are weighted

Column: 525

towards the 1- and 3-roomers, but they have also been extended towards the 4- and 5-roomers. Furthermore, the middle income group will benefit significantly from the 1% GST deferment, because their consumption level is a lot higher than the lower income group. So, we have not forgotten the middle income group in this Budget.

    Many MPs, including Mrs Fang Ai Lian, Mr Gan Kim Yong and others as well, expressed regret that we did not give further rebates for personal income tax and corporate income tax this year, nor did we lower the rates by another one percentage point. But do not forget that individuals and companies are already enjoying lower personal and corporate taxes this year, as a result of last year's substantial tax cuts. There is no justification for giving them tax rebates on top of these, considering the tight budgetary position.

    As for lowering the rates by another one percentage point, remember that it would only affect the taxes to be paid next year, in the Year of Assessment 2004. It is not going to put money in people's pockets this year. So, given the uncertainties ahead, it would be unwise of us to commit now to being generous next year. If the situation pans out favourably, it will not be too late to consider an income tax rebate next year. If it does not, we will have to reconsider our position. But what counts for investors and businesses is our long-term tax plan. For that, we have already committed to bringing down the top rates to 20% by the Year of Assessment 2005.

    On help for businesses, one item of attention has been industrial land costs. Mr Inderjit Singh, Dr John Chen, Mr Nithiah Nandan and several other MPs raised this. We cannot match the lowest land prices available in China or Vietnam, nor do we need to do so. In fact, sometimes, land is given away for free in these countries. But the Government will ensure an adequate supply of industrial land to achieve stable and internationally competitive land prices. Already, industrial

Column: 526

land prices have come down by about 45% from their peak in 1996.

    Mr Inderjit Singh suggested that the Government should announce its intention to lower industrial land prices drastically. I think the last thing the Government should do is to destabilise the property market. He may recall that, last year, he made the same proposal on residential properties - to reduce their prices by 30%. And I advised him to be very careful about what he said, because his voters who own their HDB flats would not be pleased, and they are also my voters. Unfortunately, this year, he has repeated the argument for industrial land. There are thousands of companies owning industrial land, and many banks have lent money to factories against industrial land as collateral. It would be reckless to alarm all of them with rash statements.

    We do not need to be rash. We can ensure that our land market is efficient and flexible, and that multinationals coming here have enough affordable industrial land for their operations. There is enough. We can do that because, under the Master Plan, we have reserved at least 12,000 hectares for industrial use and, so far, only 7,300 hectares of this are in use by industries. As most industrial land is held on a leasehold basis, the supply is renewable and ample to meet long-term demand. Because, every year, some leases will expire and the land is taken back and can be re-allocated again. We have also been successful in intensifying the use of the land so that we can get all the industrial floor space that we need, whether to attract new investments or to enable existing investments to expand.

    Mr Heng Chee How and several other MPs suggested that the Government's land use policy was to blame for our woes. Particularly, they cited an alleged policy whereby we priced land in terms of its alternative use. But industrial land prices are not pegged to alternative uses, such as residential or commercial purposes. Land is zoned specifically for different uses, such as for industries, and tendered out for that purpose. So, industrial uses are only competing against

Column: 527

other industrial uses, and commercial against other commercial uses, and so on. With ample supply, prices should remain competitive.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen suggested that high industrial land cost contributed to the recent PSA retrenchment. He is not right, because PSA is charged very reasonable land prices, and land cost is not a significant component of PSA's total costs. Labour is. The retrenchment in PSA is not due to land pricing but, rather, through redundant overheads. Faced with intensifying competition, PSA cannot afford to carry overheads which no longer contribute to its businesses, and they have no alternative but to rationalise.

    On rebates, a number of MPs - Dr Warren Lee, Dr Teo Ho Pin and Mr Nithiah Nandan - have asked for the various rebates which I introduced to be extended, preferably for two to three years. Members should remember that rebates are meant as temporary measures, and they should not be permanent. They are different in nature from the CPF freeze. Let me explain why.

    The CPF is a statutory cost imposed on employers and employees. It is an imposition. It achieves important social objectives, but it is a burden on businesses. We can only raise the CPF rates and increase the burden when the economy is strong enough, which means not earlier than two years from now.

    On the other hand, the JTC and HDB rental rebates are concessions to the existing tenants. In principle, tenants should pay market rentals all the time, whether the economy is up or down, and, of course, the market rentals will go up and down with the state of the economy. In that way, the companies which are viable will come into the business, and the companies which are no longer viable will leave the business. But to give the people who are already tenants, who are already in business, some respite, some time to catch their breath, we have given the rebates to help them to pay less than the market rentals, and to give them more time to adjust to the new conditions. Over

Column: 528

the long term, however, we cannot freeze this flow. We must allow the natural entry and exit of companies and businesses because, if we continue the rebates for too long, then in fact we are holding back the restructuring of our economy. So, it is better to extend the rebates for six months, and reassess the situation again next year.

    Mr Tan Soo Khoon raised the concern of Government fees and charges contributing to the cost of doing business. I have great sympathy with this view. They may be small amounts, but they do add up. We are very conscious of this, and we are making every effort to keep our fees and charges as low as possible. However, we cannot totally do away with all fees and charges. Nothing is for free. Ultimately, someone has to foot the bill. Either the users pay, or we have to fund it out of general taxes, which may mean raising tax rates. Or we will have to cut back on services and provide fewer or lower quality services, contrary to all the requests which I have heard over the last three days from MPs to improve the service quality of Government departments. Mr Tan cited DVDs getting cheaper year by year. That is true. But services are not getting cheaper year by year, unlike electronic goods, because skilled people are not getting cheaper. For example, medical costs are getting more and more expensive everywhere, as medical science and technology improve.

    The Government will make sure that its operations are run as efficiently as possible and, sometimes, this will mean retrenchments and downsizing, like in HDB. But we cannot avoid these tough choices. However, the best way to keep costs down for businesses is not through ad-hoc rebates but, rather, through prudent Government spending to keep the overall tax burden on businesses as low as possible permanently. And we have kept this Government lean, with Government spending this year accounting for only 19% of GDP. The Government will continue to keep its size small.

    Several Members - Mr Tan Soo Khoon, Mr Inderjit Singh, Mr Loh Meng See and

Column: 529

Dr John Chen - said that the deficit is not real, and that the Government should have run a bigger deficit. We did better than expected in FY 2002 because, fortunately, we underspent our budget. It is true that we had higher than projected Net Investment Income contribution but, remember, our tax revenues were lower than expected and the two variations cancelled each other out. Some Members seem to regret this. Somehow, they are sad that we did not run a deficit as big as we expected. But I am glad that, as a result, we were able to make additional special transfers to the Lifelong Learning Fund and the Medifund. However, we cannot expect such happy surprises all the time. From time to time, the Budget out-turn swings against us. For example, in FY 2001, we forecasted a budget surplus but we ended up with a deficit of $2.7 billion. And there are many uncertainties when you are looking ahead, even 12 months, especially in a year like this one.

    Therefore, we had to decide very carefully how large a deficit we needed in this FY 2003 Budget. We are running a budget deficit for the third year in a row. This is not an illusion. Where the items are meritorious, we have not cut back on spending, for example, on security. And we are making a special transfer of $600 million to the ERS account. It is a special transfer, but it is money which is going to be paid out and that will put cash directly into people's hands for them to spend if they wish.

    Mr Tan Soo Khoon also said that the Government should draw upon the surpluses of the statutory boards as a supplementary source of revenue. It is a plausible presentation of a seductive idea. The surpluses of these statutory boards have been accumulated over very many years. But on a year-to-year basis, the statutory boards are only running modest surpluses, which they ought to, because they are meant to generate sufficient revenue to fund their activities and we should be thankful that they are able to do so and do not need to fall back on Government spending.

Column: 530



    Statutory boards do make regular contributions to the Government but, compared to our overall revenue needs, these are not significant. Also, to put it bluntly, we should not be thinking of raiding the bank. We can only do it once and after that, we will be poor. It is precisely to stop populist governments from spending these reserves that the bigger statutory boards like JTC are protected with the President's second key.

    Many MPs, of course, would prefer us to have budgeted for a larger deficit so that more sweets could be distributed all round. But are they sure that a larger deficit would instill greater confidence among analysts and investors? Might analysts and investors not see it as a weakening of fiscal discipline, an inability to tighten our belts? The same people who now say that they are disappointed we did not open our purses, would turn around and say that they are alarmed that we have taken leave of our prudence.

    Mr Iswaran and others made a comparison with Hong Kong's recent Budget. This is a very, very relevant comparison. I draw three conclusions from the Hong Kong experience. Firstly, it shows how quickly a country can move from a large budget surplus to a chronic fiscal deficit. Hong Kong was in an enviable position, just a few years ago, generating a surplus of more than 6% of GDP in 1997, the year of the handover. Now, it is projecting a deficit of about HK$70 billion, 5% of GDP for this year, after running deficits for the preceding two years.

    Secondly, despite the large deficit, the Hong Kong economy is stagnant. Like Singapore, Hong Kong is a small and open economy, and deficit spending is not an effective way to boost demand. So do not think that, if only we would open our wallets, the problems would go away and we would all get a warm feeling. It is not true.

    Thirdly, once we fall into the pattern of a large deficit, it is very difficult to get out from the black hole. We may say that the spending is temporary, but the reality, as you will know from your appeals on

Column: 531

the rebates, is that it is very difficult to withdraw temporary concessions. Hong Kong is now having to raise taxes in a slow economy, which is extremely tricky, both politically and economically.

    So, given the uncertain outlook, it would be premature for us to have a highly stimulative budget to try to boost our economy. It is better for us to take a conservative stance now. If things do worsen later on, Singaporeans can take comfort that the Government has available bullets to expend. Not only should we not shoot off all our bullets now, but we need to see the situation develop further before it will be clear what targets we should aim at with our bullets so as to get maximum effect.

    These are the short-term considerations. We should also not lose sight of the longer-term dimensions, starting with the international backdrop. Global competition is intensifying. Mr Tan Soo Khoon eloquently cited some examples, so did other MPs. We have got to keep our system lean. We have got to remain nimble, and search for new growth niches and opportunities. Our past success is no guarantee of continued high growth. We can see many examples of countries which have run into difficulties because they cannot change and adapt fast enough, not that they do not know it, but they are frozen, they are unable to do it.

    For example, in Germany, as reported in the Business Week recently, enormous structural impediments have stalled Germany's progress. At the core of it all is a job protection law that makes it almost impossible for employers to lay off workers. Any company with more than five employees is subject to this law. So companies stay below six so as not to be caught. And the result of this is 11% unemployment, because the more you try to protect jobs, the fewer jobs will be created. German companies avoid hiring workers even when there is business, and they invest all over the world, rather than in Germany itself, and little foreign investment goes to Germany.

    On the other side, we see countries which are rising rapidly, like China and

Column: 532

India, which puts pressure on all other countries. China's competitive advantage will be low-cost labour for some time yet. While China dominates the world in labour-intensive products, it will also become a major importer of capital-intensive goods and knowledge-intensive services. In the longer-term, the emergence of China and India are undoubtedly positive developments for us. A more prosperous China and India would mean bigger markets, more investment opportunities, bigger trading partners for Singapore and the region.

    Our business to China is growing. We are not just importing more from them, we are exporting a lot more to them. Last year, our exports to China grew by about 28%, to more than $12 billion. Our combined exports to China and India now equal to more than half our total exports to the US. Those countries and those companies which can get organised faster would be able to move ahead and seize the opportunities that these rising economies bring with them. And some of our companies and people are already making inroads into the Chinese and Indian markets.

    For example, you may have heard of Dr Tan Hock, a Singapore entrepreneur in Shanghai, whose story was carried on some of our radio stations. He found a niche in the knowledge-based industry in China, by animating the 12 zodiac characters into cartoon characters and created an industry - cartoons as well as all the products to sell with the cartoons. And he is doing well. His creations are now broadcast in over 130 stations across China and 10 stations in Asia.

    And there are people who venture into India too. You would have read about a group of retrenched Singaporeans who made good setting up a factory producing ring binders in a small rural Indian village called Tiruvallore. When President Nathan visited Tamil Nadu recently, they turned up to meet him, which is probably how the Straits Times found out about them. It was a remote village. They went there, they set up shop, they made it viable, they even learnt Tamil, albeit a few words, and

Column: 533

I think they take turns coming home because living conditions there are hard. But they press on. And there is another company which invested half a million dollars and set up something called Technigroup India to provide modern office furniture in India. They managed to break-even within a year and generated $3 million turnover last year. The opportunities are there and we must take advantage of them. And that is the international backdrop against which we are making our domestic changes, starting with our tax changes.

    Mr Inderjit Singh asked airily what was so radical about our tax changes. It is a very significant shift to bring individual and corporate tax rates down to 20% by YA 2005 and to raise GST to broaden our tax base. How many other countries can do that? Our tax rates are competitive for now, but we will need to keep tabs over the long term and be prepared to go lower, if necessary. We are also making other strategic changes, exempting foreign source income, domestic interest income and enhancing taxation on intellectual property, and so on. As Mrs Fang Ai Lian has told Members, and she knows the business, these are important structural changes which, over time, will develop a lot of new businesses for Singapore.

    On CPF, which is our second major change, I would like to thank MPs like Mr Ong Ah Heng, Mdm Halimah and Mrs Lim Hwee Hua who have voiced support for the CPF deferment. We are grateful for their support from the unions and the workers. They have understood and accepted the need for the change.

    There is no expectation of a restoration of the CPF this year anyway. And even if the economy does moderately well this year, by January 2004, it would probably not have done strongly enough for us to be confident enough to warrant a restoration of the CPF in 2004.

    So what we are essentially asking Singaporeans to do is merely to commit

Column: 534

now what we would have to decide in 12 months anyway and to say, yes, let us decide now, we will freeze it for 24 months and get on our feet during that time. It is a commitment which we can make, and a commitment which will be an important signal to investors that we are prepared to do what it takes to get our economy back on track.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua and others raised the question of the long-term CPF structure and the question of the concept of retirement. How can we save enough in our CPF accounts while we are working, so that we can retire at 62 and then live on our CPF savings and hopefully our children for another 20 years or longer? It is not realistic and it will become an increasingly serious problem as life expectancy goes up, our population ages and our birth rate goes down.

    We have to find ways therefore to keep our older workers employed and working beyond their 50s and 60s, though not necessarily in the same job or at the same pay. Workers have to be prepared to take on second or even third careers. What can we do to help them?

    First of all, mindset change and skills upgrading are important, as pointed our by Ms Braema, Mr Seng Han Thong and Mr Andy Gan. Workers must be prepared to adapt and to make adjustments. We have to continue training to stay on the job or reskill and move on to another job, and many also have to take on lighter jobs at lower pay and work part-time. To carry on doing what you used to do, at a slower rate, and yet expecting employers to pay the same or even more, is simply not viable. But it is essential to find other work or work on different employment terms.

    We must keep the labour market flexible so as to preserve jobs and maximise employment, especially for older workers. The CPF system adds to business cost. If the CPF system is to be sustainable, it cannot impose too onerous a burden on companies to employ workers. Indeed, workers, especially those at the lower end, want more take-home pay. Hence, we are reducing employee's contributions for

Column: 535

the lower-income workers and also for the older workers aged 50-55. But there is a trade-off because if CPF contribution is too low, workers would not have saved enough for housing, healthcare or old age and, as Miss Penny Low analysed, they will fall back on the Government when they need a house, fall ill or grow old.

    So, we have to balance two perspectives - the CPF as compulsory savings, which we would like to have as high as possible, against the CPF as a cost to businesses which we would like to keep as low as possible. In the earlier years, when our growth was high and incomes were rising rapidly, we emphasised more on CPF's role as compulsory savings and pushed it up whenever we could, so as not to let people get used to spending the money. Now that we are in a tougher operating environment, we have to strike a different balance between the two perspectives. But we should not give up the first perspective of the CPF as compulsory savings entirely, because it is still valid. Without the CPF scheme, we would have a different Singapore.

    A second major theme is entrepreneurship and SMEs. Mr Raymond Lim has adequately addressed this in his speech. As Ms Indranee and Dr Chong Weng Chiew pointed out, entrepreneurial spirit is about taking personal responsibility and achieving success through his or her own efforts and abilities, rather than depending on largesse from the Government. If you say, "Please help me to become an entrepreneur", chances are you already miss one of the ingredients for starting. In many aspects, the Government should do less rather than more. It should act as a last resort, and not a first recourse.

    Yesterday, we heard Dr Gan See Khem tell us in vivid personal terms her first-hand experience, her gung-ho spirit and her passion, fighting for what she believes in. And her HMI Holdings is exactly what we are looking for. It will always be challenging to start up new businesses, and to venture outside Singapore will be even harder. If entrepreneurship was simple, and anybody could do it,

Column: 536

the rewards would not be great. Dr Gan See Khem is exceptional, as she persevered and fought against the odds. We need more people like her, and the Government will do its best to help them succeed.

    I am sorry it has taken her so long for her to deal with the agencies. I asked the agencies and they tell me that they had good reasons, and there are significant issues in assuring the standards of her training courses, but that they are doing their best to resolve these with Dr Gan expeditiously. It is our job to help, even when it does not appear that we are doing so.

    Mr Inderjit Singh suggested that we should shift our focus away from multi-nationals and rely on SMEs. He is mistaken.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): In addition to.

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: In addition to - he is correct. We will encourage small companies and start-ups but we still need the MNCs. SMEs can complement them but cannot replace them. We have hundreds of multi-nationals in Singapore. Even if our efforts to grow Singapore companies are wildly successful, we will only create a dozen or so MNCs of our own, and even that is being very, very optimistic. We need both MNCs and Singapore companies to diversify and to grow our economy and to create enough jobs for our people. However, I agree with Mr Inderjit Singh that more can be done to help SMEs navigate our bureaucracy. SPRING Singapore is the focal agency for assisting them. We have many things in mind, including helping SMEs to get access to financing in a market-based way. However, we have to bear in mind that no matter how much financing we provide, there can never be enough for all the SMEs which want it. SMEs will have to compete for financing, and only those which look viable and can convince the investors or lenders will be able to get it. This is an unavoidable Darwinian process of attrition. Without it, you will not have strong SMEs.

Column: 537



    Many MPs, Chew Heng Ching, Ng Ser Miang, Zainudin Nordin and, memorably, Dr Amy Khor, have spoken out for mindset change from the civil service to be more pro-business. Indeed, the civil service is already trying to do this, and we will have to do more. From time to time, we organise sessions in the civil service for the private sector to come and to share their perspectives with the civil servants. I will ask them, in future, to invite some MPs to speak, and I think if Dr Amy Khor and others can come and present to them the way they presented it in this House, it will have an impact, and some positive effect.

    There is a pro-enterprise panel chaired by the Head of the Civil Service, with ten members, six from the private sector, and Mr Inderjit Singh is one of the members. The panel receives feedback, suggestions and complaints from businesses against rules and on difficulties dealing with the different agencies. It has received more than 600 suggestions since it was formed in August 2000, and about half of these have been accepted. On average, it took 29 days to settle a case. Change has been quite quick, because issues are put directly to the Heads of Departments and CEOs of statutory boards. For example, we amended the Auctioneers' Licences Act as a result of feedback to the panel and this enabled on-line auctions. So, I advise anybody who is unhappy about any rule to put his case to the panel and it will give a full hearing.

    There is also a Rules Review Panel which we set up in May last year. Every Ministry and statutory board has to review all its rules within three years - that means by the end of FY 2004 - and thereafter on a five-year rolling basis, as Amy Khor says, this is a rule about rules. One result is that about one-third of 173 statutory declarations required by the Government will be removed by the end of this financial year. To give another example, Mindef reviewed 135 rules, deleted 80, simplified 40 and retained 15.

    But Prof. Low Seow Chay gave an example of a rule which we ought to

Column: 538

retain and that has to do with odour control. He was talking about chicken farms. His neighbouring MPs will know exactly what he is talking about. His complaint was that we could not specify the standard of air freshness needed or be sure what odour control process would produce fresh enough air.

    Unfortunately, smells from chicken farms pose a real problem in a compact city like Singapore. The Government did introduce a new odour control rule when we started building flats around the farms. However, it is not true that the Government kept changing the rule. The National Environment Agency is still pursuing the matter, simply because the farms have not met the required odour standards - meaning they have not installed what they were supposed to install.

    Let me tell you the real story. There were four chicken farms in Sungei Tengah. They were causing an odour problem. They were given a choice of closing down and accepting an ex gratia payment or continuing and installing odour control filters. Three closed down and took the ex gratia payment, one chose to proceed and upgrade. But after it committed to install the odour control equipment, it failed to install everything it was supposed to do, causing a great smell nuisance to residents in the neighbouring constituencies. Hence the problem, which in due course will be solved.

    But let me remind Members that after all the promotional efforts, all the rules cutting, all the incentives, whether we can be successful as an entrepreneurial society and economy, ultimately it boils down to talent. Do we have the people who can seize the opportunities? Do we have businessmen with a business sense and that drive and dare? Without them, all the efforts and the nurturing will be in vain. I think if we confine ourselves only to Singaporeans, we will not have enough entrepreneurial talent. There will be a few, but we will not have enough. If we really want to be an entrepreneurial society, we must attract foreign entrepreneurs to Singapore to start their business here, and that we are doing.

Column: 539



    Let me now talk about services. The ERC's recommendation is that we have to upgrade manufacturing and services. There is no guaranteed business, not even at the lower end. But we are confident that we can do well by upgrading what we have. Yes, others will pursue the same strategy, but I believe that we can implement this strategy better and faster than others. We have the edge, as our foundation is strong. We are nimble and we can move faster.

    Mr Khaw Boon Wan touched on services in his speech. The Government is serious about promoting this as the second engine of growth, and there is good growth potential in healthcare, education and creative services. I agree with Dr Lily Neo that we are well positioned to be a regional healthcare hub. I spoke to some private sector doctors recently and they expressed great optimism about our chances. We have traditional markets in Malaysia and Indonesia, and we are also expanding our markets further afield, to new customers like Arabs in the Middle-East, Bangladeshis, even Mongolians. I asked them, "Do Mongolians speak English?" They said at the upper end, it is no problem. They have the money, and they will come.

    Similarly for education services. Raffles LaSalle Limited now runs five schools in China, with an intake of more than 1,000 students. Today, in Singapore, we have more than 23,000 PRC students studying here. There are social considerations involved here too, and also in service sectors like healthcare. If they are really students studying, that is fine. If they are just students in name, that may be a problem. But we have to manage these problems, and we cannot turn away the business. The Ministerial Committee is going to make the trade-offs and strike the balance between the social and the economic considerations.

    We are not just targeting the high end of the services industry, as Mdm Yu-Foo Yee Shoon pointed out. There are opportunities in our traditional segments like hair-dressing, retail and entertainment. However, in Singapore, there is no

Column: 540

non-tradable sector that we can shield from competition.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann suggested that maybe if we build a strong globalised economy, then we can support an inefficient domestic sector which can provide jobs for older Singaporeans. I listened to him twice to make sure, but he did mean that - to support an inefficient domestic sector and provide some jobs. Other countries have tried that, like Japan, where in the retail sector, lots of people are employed, but they just look pretty and stand at the elevators and bow each time you go past. It has not worked for Japan, and it is not feasible for Singapore. We have no domestic service which can be shielded from global competition or from the neighbourhood.

    Mr Chiam See Tong highlighted the competition across the Causeway in healthcare services. I am not sure that I would go across to another country if I needed a heart operation, but if I need a haircut, if I want to do some shopping, or entertainment, the facilities are there, it is cheaper, why not? Many Singaporeans do. Even for bridal shops and retail outlets, there is competition. So it is not possible to have a protected inefficient domestic sector in Singapore. We have to be efficient everywhere, and we have to look after our people who cannot find jobs and help them to find jobs, which brings me to the question of structural unemployment.

    Several MPs raised this - Dr Ong Seh Hong, Mr Zainul Abidin and Dr Warren Lee. It is a difficult problem to solve. It will not disappear for quite a long time because if you look at the figures, for workers 50-59 years old, more than half have less than secondary qualifications. For the younger workers, the educational standards are higher. But even for the younger age group, aged 40-44 years old, about one-third have less than secondary qualifications, and they are going to be in the workforce for another 20 years. So the Government will go the extra mile to help these older workers. This will be one major focus of the new Continuing Education and Training statutory board.

Column: 541

These workers have contributed to the nation's growth and they have made possible what Singapore is today. Like in the PSA retrenchment exercise, we will do all that we can to help the displaced workers, counsel them, help them with job search and with job matching.

    Dr Jennifer Lee and a few other MPs also asked us to subsidise older workers. They define older workers as 40 years and above - that is a generous definition. It is a possible approach, but we do not have to consider it yet. The proportion of older workers suffering from structural unemployment is still low, only 11/2%. We should try to solve the problem for this specific group of people with targeted assistance, and not through some broad policy to subsidise many other older workers who are still managing well on their own. Otherwise, you will incur great expense and yet miss the target. Furthermore, you will distort the economy and end up with deficits and inefficiency.

    Our approach, as a Government, is a three-level one. Firstly, generate good growth and create new jobs. There are jobs available if the older workers are flexible and prepared to adapt. Even in the wafer fabs, there are semi-skilled jobs, but they will require a certain amount of discipline, adjustment or shift work. It is not easy, but it can be done. Secondly, help to educate, train and match workers to jobs so that they can stay employed, or if they lose jobs, then they can find new ones. That is the purpose of the new statutory board and also the People for Jobs Training programme. Also, we need to set up the right networks at the grassroots, the CDCs, the self-help groups and NTUC, to help workers find jobs. Thirdly, the Government will continue to provide targeted assistance to those who need help the most. But such assistance must be tied to their efforts to find jobs. The Government will also look after the younger generations to make sure that no child is deprived of good education because of lack of finances. This is a problem, because if it is too easily available, people will not look for the jobs.

Column: 542



    I was in Australia a year ago and I visited a village about 50 miles outside of the Gold Coast. I asked the guide, "Who live here?" He said, "Some teachers, some retired people, some unemployed people." I said, "Why are they living here, 50 miles away from the Gold Coast? There are no jobs." He said, "Exactly, because there is a rule in Australia that if you want the dole, you must show that you have hunted for work within a certain radius, 30-50 miles, and failed." And this was a good place for failing. So, we have to be very careful. In Singapore, there is no place to go, and if they do not try, you are going to have a problem.

    Some people have objected that many of the jobs being created are for younger, better-skilled workers. That is true. But it is important that we do create these jobs and generate the growth. With growth, we will have more resources to help the older workers. With growth, there will be some more jobs for the older workers. If we try to preserve the status quo, to protect the jobs which are no longer viable, and to put off economic restructuring, then we will fail.

    We have set as our objective here and as our theme "New Challenges - Fresh Goals". Some people have accused us of doing too little. Some people have accused us of moving too fast. MPs like Mr Inderjit Singh and Mr Leong Horn Kee have said that changes are not radical enough, and more could have been done. We have left no stone unturned. We decided where we needed to make radical changes, where modifications are needed, and where we should leave things as they are, at least for the time being. The changes are more significant than they look because we have deliberately prepared people for them and introduced them carefully. It was our purpose not to shock people.
